science.title: Science
science.heading: Precipitation Global
science.p1: AUGUR estimates extreme precipitation events at 5-kilometer resolution from the satellite product CHIRPS. The events derive from annual maximum one-day precipitation sums [mm/d] fitted by statistical distribution for extreme events.Estimated events are corrected using ground precipitation observations from GHCN. This correction allows to account for the underestimation of the satellite precipitation particularly over tropical regions.The climate change signals are computed from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Sixth Assessment Report (AR6). The data shows only the SS5-8.5 scenario.

intro.heading: What is AUGUR?
intro.p1: AUGUR helps estimate precipitation and river discharge for catchments worldwide to account for climate change.
intro.p2: This makes it possible to plan local flood assessments and adaptations to climate change – even when only limited data is available.

idea.heading: The idea
idea.p1: AUGUR combines climate information with hydrological methods and quickly delivers comparable results.
idea.p2: Scenarios and methods can be viewed side by side – making sensitivities and uncertainties visible.

technology.heading: How it works (simple)
technology.p1: AUGUR makes established scientific methods accessible in an easy-to-use web application.
technology.p2: Observational data and models are combined to estimate precipitation and runoff.
technology.p3: In the background, a robust API ensures that calculations can be performed simultaneously.

list.svelte: SvelteKit interface for maps, charts and projects.
list.fastapi: FastAPI provides the API and authentication (Keycloak).
list.prisma: Prisma handles database access for projects and results.
list.celery: Celery runs hydrologic models as background jobs.
list.redis: Redis coordinates tasks and short‑lived results.
list.docker: Docker Compose runs the stack locally and in the cloud.

getting_started.heading: Get started
getting_started.p1: Try the Precipitation tool or create a Discharge project. Adjust inputs and rerun to compare results.

credits.heading: Credits & data
credits.p1: AUGUR is open source and was launched for global use with the support of the 'Innovation Meets Practice Accelerator' 2022 of the Humanitarian Aid of the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC).
credits.p2: With funding from the Canton of Bern, AUGUR was further developed with the methods of HAKESCH and a rainfall-runoff model (NAM) in collaboration with Hunziker, Zarn und Partner (HZP) and Scherrer Hydrologie.

login.title: Sign in to AUGUR
login.why_heading: Why do I need an account?
login.why_p1: Signing in lets you save projects, revisit results and keep your data private.
login.why_p2: It also helps us run longer hydrologic calculations reliably in the background.
login.free_p1: Registration is free. You can delete your projects at any time.
login.privacy_note: We only use your information to provide this service.
